questions.text:
A 29-year-old man arrives at the Emergency Department after a high-speed motorcycle collision. He is pale, diaphoretic, and complains of severe abdominal pain. He has no known medical history. Examination shows a markedly tender abdomen with guarding (see report).


Heart rate
132/min


Blood pressure
84/50 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
28/min


Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST): Large hypoechoic collection in the hepatorenal recess
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Abdominal CT scan with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with serial exams is for stable patients with low hemorrhage risk. This patient is hemodynamically unstable, with tachycardia, hypotension, and severe abdominal pain, indicating shock and intra-abdominal injury. The FAST exam suggests significant hemorrhage, making observation inappropriate due to the risk of delayed intervention.

B) CORRECT:

The FAST exam reveals a large hypoechoic collection in the hepatorenal recess, indicating significant intraperitoneal free fluid, likely blood from an injured organ. In blunt trauma with hemodynamic instability, characterized by tachycardia, hypotension, and shock, free fluid on FAST suggests ongoing hemorrhage. Immediate exploratory laparotomy is necessary to locate and control the bleeding source, aligning with trauma guidelines for unstable patients with positive FAST findings.

Key learning point: The FAST exam is primarily used to detect intraperitoneal free fluid in trauma patients, indicating potential internal bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) detects occult intraperitoneal hemorrhage when noninvasive studies are inconclusive. In this patient, a positive FAST exam and hemodynamic instability confirm intra-abdominal bleeding. DPL is redundant here, as it does not localize the bleeding source and carries unnecessary risks.

D) INCORRECT:

CT with intravenous contrast is useful for stable patients to delineate intra-abdominal injuries. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, with hypotension and tachycardia, and has a positive FAST exam indicating intra-abdominal hemorrhage. Transporting an unstable patient to CT risks further decompensation and delays necessary surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with severe, sudden-onset epigastric pain radiating to his back. Vital signs are BP, 90/60; P, 110. He appears diaphoretic. Physical examination shows a pulsatile epigastric mass. Initial point-of-care ultrasound examination shows significant bowel gas obscuring the proximal abdominal aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the ultrasound evaluation?

choices.text: Switch to a linear array transducer for better resolution
Rotate the transducer 180° to change the acoustic window
Apply color Doppler to distinguish the aorta from adjacent structures
Increase the ultrasound frequency to penetrate through bowel gas
Obtain lateral views with the patient in left lateral decubitus position

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Linear array transducers have high frequency and low depth penetration, making them unsuitable for abdominal aortic assessment. Linear array transducers are designed for superficial structures and do not improve visualization through bowel gas.

B) INCORRECT:

Rotating the transducer 180° only changes the orientation of the image on the screen and does not provide a different acoustic window. This maneuver does not address the bowel gas obstruction that is preventing adequate visualization.

C) INCORRECT:

Color Doppler can help distinguish the aorta from adjacent structures and assess luminal patency, but it does not address the primary problem of bowel gas obstruction. The underlying anatomy must first be visualized for color Doppler assessment to be meaningful.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing frequency decreases depth penetration and worsens visualization of deep abdominal structures. Lower frequencies are needed for deeper penetration, and bowel gas remains a fundamental impediment regardless of frequency adjustments.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- When bowel gas obscures the standard subxiphoid approach, the first step is to attempt displacement by rocking the transducer back and forth while applying firm but gentle pressure over the area of interest. If this displacement technique is unsuccessful, obtaining lateral views is a second-line approach that provides an alternative acoustic window. The patient is positioned in left lateral decubitus position with the transducer placed in the right midaxillary line to visualize the aorta through the liver, which serves as an acoustic window that bypasses bowel gas obstruction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with heart failure presents with abdominal discomfort. Point-of-care ultrasound reveals a 3.4-cm tubular structure in the mid-abdomen with decreased pulsatility. Bowel gas partially obscures portions of the examination. Which of the following features most reliably distinguishes the aorta from the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-velocity flow on color Doppler can be seen in both arterial and venous structures depending on hemodynamic conditions. While expansile pulsations and high-velocity color flow are typical sonographic signs of the aorta, velocity alone is not the most reliable distinguishing feature, particularly in patients with altered hemodynamics or cardiac dysfunction.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The aorta remains noncompressible under transducer pressure. This feature can be used to distinguish the aorta from the inferior vena cava as it persists even when other identifying features, such as pulsatility, are diminished due to cardiac conditions. The noncompressible nature of the aorta reflects the thick muscular wall structure of the arterial system.

C) INCORRECT:

The aorta typically appears further from the orientation marker in transverse view when a conventional transducer orientation is used (i.e., with the marker pointing towards the patient's right). However, if an alternate transducer orientation is used or the patient has situs inversus, the aorta will appear closer to the marker, making this feature a less reliable way of distinguishing the aorta from the inferior vena cava.

D) INCORRECT:

While the aorta diameter does not typically vary with inspiration, this finding can be affected by patient positioning, breathing effort, and underlying cardiopulmonary conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral positioning may improve visualization of either the aorta or inferior vena cava when bowel gas interferes with the standard approach but does not help to differentiate between vessel types.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with 8 hours of severe right upper quadrant pain and nausea. She is afebrile and has not eaten since yesterday evening. Point-of-care ultrasound shows multiple echogenic intraluminal foci with posterior acoustic shadowing in the gallbladder. The gallbladder measures 9 cm in length with an anteroposterior diameter of 5 cm. The anterior wall thickness measures 6 mm. No pericholecystic fluid is visualized. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The findings are consistent with acute cholecystitis. The gallbladder wall thickness of 6 mm exceeds the normal 3–5 mm threshold for fasting patients, and the dimensions of 9 cm length with 5 cm anteroposterior diameter indicate distention. These inflammatory changes, combined with the presence of gallstones, support acute cholecystitis rather than simple cholelithiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

The gallbladder wall thickness of 6 mm exceeds the normal 3–5 mm threshold for fasting patients. The combination of wall thickening and distention indicates inflammatory changes beyond simple stone presence.

C) INCORRECT:

Gallbladder polyps do not cause posterior acoustic shadowing and are typically fixed to the gallbladder wall without movement on repositioning. The strong posterior acoustic shadowing indicates gallstones rather than polyps.

D) INCORRECT:

Biliary sludge appears as low-level echogenic material in the dependent portion of the gallbladder without strong posterior acoustic shadowing. The findings of highly echogenic foci with strong posterior acoustic shadowing are characteristic of gallstones, not sludge.

E) INCORRECT:

Cholangitis typically manifests with Charcot triad and requires visualization of common bile duct abnormalities. This patient's findings are localized to the gallbladder and do not suggest biliary tree involvement or the systemic inflammatory response in cholangitis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with diabetes presents with 8 hours of epigastric pain radiating to the right shoulder and nausea. Vital signs are T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); P, 102; BP, 128/78. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A point-of-care ultrasound is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with oral antibiotics and follow-up
Administer IV antibiotics and surgical consultation
Obtain CT scan of the abdomen with IV contrast
Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography for stone extraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ultrasound findings of gallbladder wall thickening > 3–5 mm with pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic rim) along with fever and clinical presentation indicate acute cholecystitis. This condition requires inpatient management with IV antibiotics.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ultrasound findings of gallbladder wall thickening > 3–5 mm and pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic rim) combined with fever and clinical presentation confirm acute cholecystitis. This condition requires immediate IV antibiotics and surgical consultation for potential cholecystectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

While CT scan can provide additional information, the ultrasound findings already show classic signs of acute cholecystitis. The priority is initiating appropriate treatment rather than obtaining additional imaging that would delay management.

D) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is indicated for choledocholithiasis with common bile duct stones, not for acute cholecystitis. The ultrasound shows gallstones within the gallbladder, not evidence of common bile duct obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute cholecystitis requires urgent intervention, not elective surgery. The fever, ultrasound findings, and clinical presentation indicate active inflammation that should be treated immediately to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with 8 hours of progressive abdominal pain and multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. He underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 years ago. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows abdominal distention without peritoneal signs. A point-of-care ultrasound of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with oral contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ultrasound findings of dilated small bowel greater than 2.5 cm with visible plicae circulares (keyboard sign) and decreased peristalsis are consistent with small bowel obstruction. Nasogastric decompression is the immediate next step to decompress the bowel, provide symptomatic relief, and prevent aspiration. This patient requires urgent stabilization before any advanced imaging or surgical intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are not indicated for small bowel obstruction. This patient's symptoms are mechanical rather than related to gastric acid production, and proton pump inhibitors would not address the underlying obstruction or provide symptomatic relief.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate for a patient with ultrasound findings consistent with small bowel obstruction. This condition requires hospital admission, decompression, and close monitoring for potential complications such as bowel ischemia or perforation.

D) INCORRECT:

While CT imaging may eventually be needed for further evaluation, immediate nasogastric decompression takes priority in a patient with clear ultrasound evidence of small bowel obstruction. Oral contrast is contraindicated in bowel obstruction because it cannot pass through the obstruction and may worsen symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is contraindicated in complete mechanical bowel obstruction. As a prokinetic agent, metoclopramide increases gastric contractions and duodenal motility, which could worsen the obstruction and potentially lead to bowel perforation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with acute abdominal pain. She reports intermittent epigastric discomfort for the past month, which progressed to severe and constant pain 3 hours ago. Vital signs are T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); P, 110; BP, 95/60. Physical examination shows abdominal distension with diffuse tenderness and voluntary guarding. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a hypoechoic collection in the hepatorenal space in addition to the finding shown. Which of the following is the most important next step in management?

choices.text: Order contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This unstable patient already has clinical and sonographic evidence of peritonitis due to pneumoperitoneum and intraperitoneal free fluid. While an upright chest x-ray can detect pneumoperitoneum, it has limited sensitivity, and findings rarely have a significant impact on patient management when clinical suspicion for bowel perforation is high. Additional imaging would unnecessarily delay definitive treatment in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The point-of-care ultrasound finding shown is the enhanced peritoneal stripe sign (EPSS), characterized by hyperechogenic focal thickening of the peritoneum with reverberation artifacts. The EPSS is a sign of pneumoperitoneum from free air collecting anteriorly and creating a highly reflective interface. EPSS combined with this patient's presentation (fever, hemodynamic instability, and peritoneal signs) strongly suggests bowel perforation, which requires urgent surgical consultation for emergency exploratory laparotomy. The presence of free intraperitoneal fluid (hypoechoic collection in hepatorenal space) further supports the diagnosis of perforation with leakage of gastrointestinal contents.

C) INCORRECT:

The point-of-care and clinical findings in this patient are consistent with intestinal perforation. While antibiotics and analgesics are helpful supportive care measures, this patient requires a more definitive intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

While CT abdomen provides detailed imaging, this patient presents with hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia) and evidence of acute pathology on point-of-care ultrasound. In unstable patients with concerning clinical findings, additional imaging can inappropriately delay time-sensitive interventions.

E) INCORRECT:

The point-of-care ultrasound finding suggests intraperitoneal free air. Diagnostic paracentesis would not yield additional clinically relevant information and would delay management while adding procedural risks in an unstable patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old construction worker is brought to the emergency department of a trauma center with left chest pain and dyspnea after a fall from scaffolding. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 100; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. eFAST examination of the left chest at the second intercostal space is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient has an eFAST finding consistent with a left-sided pneumothorax, they are currently stable and do not require immediate chest tube insertion based on current hemodynamic and respiratory status.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Assessing for bilateral pneumothorax in a patient with pneumothorax is critical to guiding management decisions, ventilation approach, and urgency of intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

While CT chest may be indicated later to assess for thoracic trauma in greater detail, the priority is completing the primary survey first as per advanced trauma life support. Moving to CT prematurely could delay the immediate care of related injuries that should be identified first.

D) INCORRECT:

While oxygen is appropriate, failing to assess the contralateral lung could miss bilateral pneumothorax, a potentially life-threatening condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Intubation and positive pressure ventilation in a patient with a pneumothorax can convert it to a life-threatening tension pneumothorax. Intubation should be avoided unless absolutely necessary; if intubation is required, chest decompression should be performed first.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and progressive dyspnea following a motor vehicle collision. Vital signs are BP, 85/60; P, 125. He has distended neck veins. A focused cardiac ultrasound is performed. What finding is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium throughout the cardiac cycle
Hypoechoic fluid collection posterior to the diaphragm
Hyperechoic space between pericardium and epicardium observable in systole only
Echogenic material between pericardium and epicardium with organized septations
Collapsed inferior vena cava with high collapsibility index

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium throughout the cardiac cycle indicates effusions greater than 50 mL, which is consistent with this patient's hemodynamic compromise. Hypotension and distended neck veins suggest significant pericardial effusion causing tamponade physiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypoechoic fluid collection posterior to the diaphragm indicates pleural effusion, not pericardial effusion. While both conditions can manifest with fluid collections on ultrasound, pericardial effusion appears as anechoic space between the pericardium and epicardium. False positives on ultrasound are possible when pericardial fluid is mistaken for pleural fluid, but focused cardiac ultrasound should identify the correct anatomical location.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperechoic spaces appear brighter on ultrasound and are not characteristic of pericardial effusion. Epicardial fat may appear hyperechoic but moves with the myocardium and does not collect in dependent regions such as fluid.

D) INCORRECT:

Organized septations are more characteristic of complex pleural effusions or loculated collections than typical pericardial effusions. While hemorrhagic effusions may be echogenic, organized septations are unusual in acute trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Collapsed inferior vena cava (IVC) with a high collapsibility index suggests volume depletion, which contradicts this patient's clinical presentation of suspected tamponade with distended neck veins and hemodynamic compromise. Expected findings in cardiac tamponade are hepatic vein and IVC plethora, not IVC collapse.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with acute onset dyspnea and orthopnea. Vital signs are BP, 82/45; P, 110;  oxygen saturation, 87% on room air. A focused cardiac ultrasound with a parasternal long-axis view is obtained as part of the initial evaluation. What assessment technique is most appropriate to rapidly assess left ventricular systolic function?

choices.text: Qualitative visual assessment of ventricular wall thickening during systole
Assessment of left ventricular chamber size during diastole
Evaluation of aortic valve opening and closing motion
Measurement of left ventricular end-diastolic dimension
Assessment of interventricular septal motion and thickening

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – In focused cardiac ultrasound, left ventricular systolic function is assessed qualitatively by observing ventricular wall thickening and near apposition during systole. This rapid visual assessment allows emergency physicians to categorize cardiac function as hyperdynamic, normal, or hypodynamic without time-consuming calculations, which enables immediate clinical decision-making in critically ill patients. The qualitative approach is essential when rapid assessment is necessary to guide emergency management decisions.

B) INCORRECT:

Assessment of left ventricular chamber size evaluates ventricular dimensions rather than systolic function. While chamber size can be assessed on a parasternal long-axis view and may suggest chronic conditions, this assessment does not provide information about the contractile performance and pumping ability of the ventricle.

C) INCORRECT:

While aortic valve opening and closing motion can be observed on the parasternal long-axis view, this assessment primarily evaluates valve mechanics rather than left ventricular systolic function. In contrast, assessment of anterior mitral valve leaflet motion is part of the evaluation of global left ventricular function. Normal mitral leaflet motion during diastole indicates proper ventricular filling and relaxation.

D) INCORRECT:

While left ventricular end-diastolic dimension (LVEDD) can be measured on the parasternal long-axis view and provides structural information, it primarily reflects chamber size rather than contractile function. Although LVEDD can suggest volume status or chronic remodeling, it does not directly assess the dynamic contractile performance and wall motion that define systolic function. In emergency settings that require rapid functional evaluation, individual dimensional measurements are not as practical or informative as a global assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

While interventricular septal motion can be observed on the parasternal long-axis view, septal assessment provides only regional information about one coronary territory. Regional wall motion abnormalities can occur even if other left ventricular segments function normally. For rapid assessment of global left ventricular systolic function, comprehensive visual evaluation of all visible ventricular segments provides more clinically relevant information than isolated septal assessment alone.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of recent orthopedic surgery presents with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. Vital signs are BP, 85/45; P, 125; SpO2, 86% on room air. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. Focused cardiac ultrasound is shown. Troponin is elevated at 0.8 ng/mL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent cardiology consultation for percutaneous coronary intervention

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of hemodynamic instability, characteristic echocardiographic findings of acute right heart strain (right ventricular enlargement equal to left ventricular volume with septal flattening), and high clinical suspicion for pulmonary embolism in a patient with recent surgery indicates massive pulmonary embolism. In hemodynamically unstable patients with a high clinical probability of massive pulmonary embolism, immediate systemic thrombolysis is the treatment of choice and should not be delayed for imaging confirmation.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical embolectomy is reserved for patients who have contraindications to thrombolysis, unsuccessful thrombolytic therapy, or are in extremis. Surgical embolectomy is not the first-line treatment for massive pulmonary embolism and requires immediate surgical availability.

C) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiogram is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with suspected pulmonary embolism; this patient is hemodynamically unstable, evidenced by hypotension. Delaying treatment for imaging in massive pulmonary embolism can be life-threatening.

D) INCORRECT:

While elevated troponin might suggest acute coronary syndrome, the echocardiographic findings of isolated right heart strain with right ventricular enlargement and septal flattening are not consistent with acute myocardial infarction. These findings specifically suggest acute pulmonary vascular obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

While anticoagulation is important in pulmonary embolism management, empiric heparin alone is insufficient for massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic compromise. The patient requires immediate reperfusion therapy with thrombolysis to address the life-threatening obstruction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old tall, thin man presents with sudden onset of left-sided chest pain and dyspnea that started 30 minutes ago during a volleyball game. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination shows decreased breath sounds on the left side. A basic lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE) protocol performed at the left upper BLUE point shows absent lung sliding. What is the most likely M-mode finding at this location?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- In the stratosphere sign (also called barcode sign), horizontal lines appear throughout the entire M-mode field and the granular pattern from moving visceral pleura is absent. This sign occurs when lung sliding is absent, as seen in pneumothorax.

B) INCORRECT:

Alternating seashore and stratosphere signs represent the lung point, which is pathognomonic for pneumothorax but not always present, especially in large pneumothoraces.

C) INCORRECT:

A granular pattern throughout suggests normal visceral pleural movement, which contradicts the absent pleural sliding in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The seashore sign consists of horizontal lines proximally (waves) and a granular pattern distally (sand), representing normal lung sliding. This sign is not present when pleural sliding is absent.

E) INCORRECT:

A sinusoid pattern is characteristic of pleural effusion on M-mode, in which the distance between pleural layers varies with respiration due to fluid separation. Sinusoid pattern is not consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea over 2 days. A basic lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE) protocol performed at the upper and lower BLUE points bilaterally is shown. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiology?

choices.text: Increased pulmonary tissue density from fluid accumulation
Normal aerated lung tissue with reverberation artifacts
Fluid separating visceral and parietal pleura
Air in the pleural space preventing pleural sliding

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The findings show multiple pulmonary B-lines, which are hyperechoic vertical lines that move with respiration and do not fade with depth. B-lines indicate increased pulmonary tissue density from fluid accumulation, consistent with alveolar-interstitial syndrome, and correlate with Kerley-B lines on chest x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal aerated lung tissue produces pulmonary A-lines, which are horizontal hyperechoic lines parallel to the pleural line that fade with increasing distance from the probe. The vertical lines that do not fade represent pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

Lung consolidation produces the shred sign with irregular hyperechoic lines and tissue-like echogenicity distal to the pleural line. The finding of vertical lines extending from the pleural line represents a different pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluid separating the pleural layers produces the quad sign with parallel horizontal hyperechoic lines and a sinusoid pattern on M-mode. A pleural effusion would not produce the vertical artifacts seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Air in the pleural space causes absent lung sliding and potentially a visible lung point, producing the stratosphere sign on M-mode. This patient's findings indicate preserved lung sliding with vertical artifacts.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recurrent acute-onset left flank pain. Point-of-care ultrasound is shown. Vital signs are normal and she has no fever. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT urography is used for further evaluation of genitourinary abnormalities when additional imaging is needed, but it is not indicated as the immediate next step when mild hydronephrosis has already been identified on ultrasound in a stable patient.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The ultrasound findings show mild hydronephrosis (dilation of renal pelvis and major calyces only). In a young patient presenting with recurrent acute flank pain and mild hydronephrosis, urolithiasis is the most likely cause. Conservative management with adequate pain control and hydration is appropriate for stable patients, as many small stones pass spontaneously.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate urological consultation is not indicated for mild hydronephrosis in a stable patient with no signs of infection or complete obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography is a specialized imaging study used to determine the degree of hydronephrosis and localize obstruction if initial testing is inconclusive. It offers little additional benefit over CT imaging and involves IV contrast exposure, making it an inappropriate immediate next step for mild hydronephrosis in a stable patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrostomy tube placement is reserved for severe hydronephrosis with signs of infection, complete obstruction, or kidney dysfunction. It is not indicated for mild hydronephrosis in a stable patient.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with altered mental status undergoes bedside ultrasound evaluation. The images generated by a curvilinear probe placed in the midline above the pubic symphysis are shown. What does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic free fluid appears as anechoic areas in dependent portions of the pelvis (such as the pouch of Douglas), but it does not appear as a single, well-defined anechoic space with distinct hyperechoic walls in the suprapubic location shown. Free pelvic fluid typically collects in the most dependent parts of the pelvis and is not contained by defined structures.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's sonographic findings are pathognomonic for bladder distension. A distended bladder appears as an anechoic (fluid-filled) space surrounded by hyperechoic walls, with posterior acoustic enhancement. In older adults with altered mental status, urinary retention is a common and potentially reversible cause of delirium that requires immediate catheterization. The bladder volume can be calculated using the formula: 0.52 × depth × width × height. A post-void residual > 50 mL (> 100 mL in patients > 65 years of age) usually indicates urinary retention that requires intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine enlargement does not appear as a simple anechoic space with hyperechoic walls. The uterus has characteristic mixed echogenicity with identifiable myometrium and endometrial layers. On transvaginal or transabdominal ultrasound, an enlarged uterus (e.g., due to fibroids or pregnancy) shows the typical uterine architecture with varying echogenicity patterns, not the homogeneous anechoic appearance seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

On ultrasound, bowel obstruction appears as multiple fluid-filled dilated bowel loops (> 2.5 cm diameter) with heterogeneous contents. Characteristic findings include the piano key sign (prominent plicae circulares), altered peristalsis, and thickened bowel walls. Bowel obstruction does not appear as a single large anechoic space.

E) INCORRECT:

A large, simple ovarian cyst can appear as an anechoic space with thin hyperechoic walls, similar to a distended bladder. Simple ovarian cysts appear as thin-walled, smooth, anechoic, unilocular cystic lesions and can grow to significant sizes (≥ 7 cm). However, large ovarian cysts are less likely to appear centrally in the midline suprapubic region and do not explain altered mental status in a 72-year-old patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. Her vital signs are normal, and her pregnancy test is positive. A point-of-care transabdominal pelvic ultrasound is performed. What is the most appropriate initial step to locate the area of interest?

choices.text: Scan in the sagittal plane at the midline above the pubic symphysis
Scan in the transverse plane with the indicator pointing toward the patient's right side
Scan in the longitudinal plane aligned with the uterine axis
Scan with the transducer positioned laterally from midline
Scan with color Doppler applied throughout the plane

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The most appropriate initial technique is to start in the sagittal plane with the transducer placed at the midline, just above the pubic symphysis, with the indicator pointing toward the patient's head. This allows identification of the fluid-distended bladder and, subsequently, the uterus posterior and inferior to the bladder. The endometrial stripe can then be identified within the uterus as the initial area of interest for ruling in an intrauterine pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

The transverse plane is used later in the examination after initial identification of structures in the sagittal plane. The transverse orientation with the indicator pointing toward the patient's right side is performed after rotating the transducer counterclockwise from the initial sagittal position.

C) INCORRECT:

The uterus must first be identified and located before the transducer can be aligned with its long axis. Initial scanning begins in the sagittal plane at the midline to identify the bladder and uterus, then the transducer is rotated to align with the uterine axis.

D) INCORRECT:

Scanning with the transducer positioned laterally from midline is not an appropriate starting point for basic point-of-care ultrasound evaluation of early pregnancy. The first step is to identify the uterus relative to the bladder to confirm an intrauterine pregnancy. Evaluation of lateral pelvic structures such as adnexae and ovaries is typically done during formal pelvic ultrasound for fetal viability.

E) INCORRECT:

Color Doppler should be avoided in the first trimester due to risks to the fetus. Basic point-of-care ultrasound for early pregnancy focuses on identifying structural signs of intrauterine pregnancy without using Doppler techniques.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with mild lower abdominal cramping and scant vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks and 4 days ago, and a urine pregnancy test is positive. Vital signs are normal, and pelvic examination reveals a closed cervix. Serum β-hCG is 800 mIU/mL. What is the most likely transvaginal ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The double decidual sac sign has a hypoechogenic center surrounded by two concentric echogenic rings within the uterine cavity. While this finding may increase the likelihood of intrauterine pregnancy, it is not consistently present and is not the primary earliest sonographic sign at this gestational age.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The gestational sac is the earliest sonographic sign of possible intrauterine pregnancy, appearing as a small anechoic spherical structure within the endometrial cavity. It becomes identifiable by 4 and a half to 5 weeks' gestational age and may only be 2–3 mm in size. At approximately 4 weeks and 4 days' gestational age with a β-hCG of 800 mIU/mL, only the gestational sac is likely to be visible on ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

The fetal pole appears as an echogenic thickening attached to the inner wall of the yolk sac and is a definitive sign of intrauterine pregnancy. The fetal pole becomes visible at around 6 weeks' gestational age, which is approximately 10 days later than this patient's presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal heart activity is a definitive sign of a viable intrauterine pregnancy that becomes identifiable at around 6 weeks' gestational age. At this patient's early gestational age of less than 5 weeks, fetal heart activity is not expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The yolk sac is the earliest definitive sign of intrauterine pregnancy, appearing as a 3–5 mm spherical structure with an echogenic rim eccentrically located within the gestational sac. The yolk sac typically becomes identifiable at around 5 and a half weeks' gestational age, which is significantly later than this patient's gestational age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with cramping and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. A bedside point-of-care ultrasound using a curvilinear probe shows an intrauterine gestational sac containing a yolk sac and fetal pole with visible cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate next step to quantify fetal heart rate?

choices.text: Activate the built-in fetal heart rate calculator in B-mode
Apply color Doppler to assess cardiac flow patterns
Switch to M-mode and measure peak-to-peak intervals
Increase probe frequency to improve temporal resolution
Adjust gain settings to enhance cardiac visualization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The built-in fetal heart rate calculator requires M-mode to function properly. B-mode imaging alone does not provide the temporal resolution necessary for accurate heart rate measurement because it cannot display cyclical cardiac motion over time.

B) INCORRECT:

Color Doppler should be avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus. M-mode provides adequate assessment of fetal heart rate without the theoretical thermal and mechanical effects of Doppler ultrasound.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- After optimizing the view of fetal cardiac activity, switching to M-mode displays a sinusoidal wave pattern that represents cardiac motion over time. The screen is then frozen, and calipers are used to measure the peak-to-peak distance between waves, which allows the machine to calculate the heart rate automatically.

D) INCORRECT:

Curvilinear probes operating at 3–5 MHz are appropriate for fetal assessment because they provide adequate penetration for deep abdominal structures. Higher frequency probes have limited penetration and do not improve heart rate assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Once cardiac activity is optimized and visible, adjusting gain settings does not improve heart rate quantification. Gain controls the brightness of echoes but does not provide the temporal resolution needed to accurately measure heart rate from cardiac motion patterns.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of myopia presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset vision loss in his left eye that began 2 hours ago. He describes it as a “curtain falling” over his vision and reports seeing flashes of light prior to the vision loss. He has no history of recent trauma. Vital signs are normal, and examination of the right eye is unremarkable. Point-of-care ultrasound is performed using a 10 MHz linear array probe. What is the most likely finding on ocular ultrasound?

choices.text: Mobile, hyperechoic band anterior to the choroid
Anechoic fluid behind the eye with globe distortion
Lens displacement with anterior chamber collapse

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- A mobile, hyperechoic band anterior to the choroid is the characteristic ultrasound finding for retinal detachment. This finding correlates with the curtain-like vision loss and preceding flashes of light, which are classic symptoms of retinal detachment.

B) INCORRECT:

A cloudy, hyperechoic posterior chamber suggests vitreous hemorrhage. While this can cause vision loss, it typically manifests with floaters or hazy vision rather than curtain-like vision loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Anechoic fluid behind the eye with globe distortion indicates retrobulbar hematoma. This typically occurs following orbital trauma and manifests with additional signs such as proptosis, restricted eye movements, and severe pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Echogenic material within the globe suggests an intraocular foreign body. This finding is inconsistent with the absence of trauma history and the symptoms described by this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lens displacement with anterior chamber collapse indicates lens dislocation, which usually follows significant blunt trauma. Anterior chamber collapse also suggests possible globe rupture, which is inconsistent with this patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with sudden onset of painless vision loss in the right eye that began 6 hours ago. The patient reports seeing floaters and describes the vision as particularly poor upon awakening. Visual acuity is 20/200 in the affected eye. A point-of-care ocular ultrasound is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the orbits is appropriate for suspected orbital fracture or retrobulbar hematoma. This patient's ultrasound findings and absent history of trauma are inconsistent with these diagnoses.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ultrasound findings of a cloudy, hyperechoic posterior chamber indicate vitreous hemorrhage. In a patient with diabetes and sudden painless vision loss, this likely represents bleeding from proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Immediate ophthalmology consultation is required for further evaluation and potential intervention, as vitreous hemorrhage can lead to permanent vision loss if not properly managed.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotic drops are indicated for an infectious process. The cloudy posterior chamber findings in this patient most likely represent blood, given this patient's clinical picture, not inflammatory material.

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent brain MRI can reveal central causes of vision loss. This patient's clinical picture and ultrasound findings are consistent with intraocular pathology rather than retrobulbar or central nervous system causes.

E) INCORRECT:

The ultrasound findings of a cloudy, hyperechoic posterior chamber indicate vitreous hemorrhage. Bed rest with head elevation and activity restriction are conservative measures used in the wait-and-see approach for vitreous hemorrhage, as hemorrhage may resolve spontaneously. This patient's underlying diabetes and acute vision loss raise concern for underlying proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires urgent intervention.

questions.text: A 32-year-old machinist presents 6 hours after sustaining a puncture wound to his right palm while handling sheet metal. Physical examination shows a small entry wound with minimal bleeding and no obvious foreign material visible. The patient reports persistent sharp pain with finger movement. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is performed to evaluate for a retained foreign body. What ultrasound finding is most characteristic of a metallic foreign body?

choices.text: Reverberation artifacts from the metallic surface
Increased echogenicity of surrounding subcutaneous tissue
Hypoechoic halo surrounding the metallic fragment
Posterior acoustic enhancement deep to the object
Acoustic shadow from the metallic object

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Reverberation artifacts are the characteristic finding on ultrasound for smooth metallic foreign bodies. These occur when sound waves bounce back and forth between the transducer and the metallic surface, creating multiple parallel echogenic lines at regular intervals.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased echogenicity of surrounding subcutaneous tissue with a cobblestone appearance is characteristic of cellulitis, not a foreign body. This finding represents inflammatory changes in infected soft tissue rather than foreign material.

C) INCORRECT:

While a hypoechoic halo may develop around foreign bodies as part of the inflammatory response, this typically occurs after 24 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Posterior acoustic enhancement occurs with fluid-filled structures like abscesses, not metallic foreign bodies. This finding indicates increased echogenicity deep to a fluid collection due to reduced sound wave attenuation.

E) INCORRECT:

Acoustic shadowing is characteristic of irregular foreign bodies such as wood splinters, not smooth metallic objects. Metal typically produces reverberation artifacts rather than clean acoustic shadows due to its smooth surface properties.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of leg pain and swelling following what she describes as "a small scratch" from gardening. On examination, there is mild erythema and tenderness over the anterior shin with minimal induration. Vital signs are BP, 135/82; P, 88; T, 37.9°C (100.2°F). Point-of-care ultrasound of the affected area is performed. Which of the following ultrasound findings is most concerning and requires immediate surgical consultation?

choices.text: Hypoechoic strands between subcutaneous fat tissue
Highly echogenic areas with posterior acoustic shadowing in the fascial planes
Hyperechoic linear structure with multiple parallel reverberation artifacts
Discrete anechoic regions with posterior acoustic enhancement in subcutaneous tissues
Noncompressible hypoechoic tubular structure in the deep posterior compartment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This finding (also known as a cobblestone appearance) represents edema within the subcutaneous tissue and is characteristic of cellulitis, which is most often managed with antibiotics. While a cobblestone appearance indicates soft tissue infection, it alone does not suggest deeper tissue involvement or necrosis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This describes gas shadowing, which strongly suggests necrotizing fasciitis. The highly echogenic (bright) areas represent gas produced by bacteria, and the posterior acoustic shadowing occurs because the gas prevents sound transmission through deeper tissues. This finding, particularly in the fascial planes, indicates tissue necrosis that requires immediate surgical consultation for emergency debridement.

C) INCORRECT:

The hyperechoic linear appearance with reverberation artifacts is characteristic of foreign objects, particularly metallic ones, that create multiple parallel echoes. While foreign bodies warrant evaluation, can predispose to infection, and often need removal, urgent surgical consultation is rarely necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Superficial subcutaneous fluid collections suggest abscess or seroma formation. While superficial subcutaneous fluid collections may necessitate drainage, they do not on their own indicate deep tissue involvement or necrosis that requires urgent surgical consultation.

E) INCORRECT:

A noncompressible hypoechoic tubular appearance is classic for deep vein thrombosis of the posterior tibial or peroneal veins. Deep vein thrombosis can typically be managed with anticoagulation and rarely requires urgent surgical consultation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with diabetes presents with a 5-day history of progressive forearm pain and swelling after a minor laceration. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a 6-cm area of erythema, warmth, and induration. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a 3-cm hypoechoic collection with posterior acoustic enhancement and positive compressibility on probe pressure. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Ultrasound findings of a hypoechoic collection with posterior acoustic enhancement and positive compressibility (squish sign) are diagnostic for an abscess. These ultrasound findings distinguish an abscess from cellulitis and indicate incision and drainage as definitive treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics alone are insufficient for the underlying cause of this patient's ultrasound findings. This approach is more appropriate if the ultrasound showed increased echogenicity with a cobblestone appearance of subcutaneous tissue, consistent with cellulitis. This patient's ultrasound findings of a discrete compressible collection with posterior acoustic enhancement suggest a different pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

IV antibiotics may be appropriate for cellulitis, but they do not adequately address the underlying cause of ultrasound findings of a discrete compressible collection with posterior acoustic enhancement.

D) INCORRECT:

Needle aspiration is inadequate treatment for the condition causing these ultrasound findings. This approach typically results in recurrence and incomplete resolution of the underlying pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate if ultrasound shows a discrete hypoechoic collection with posterior acoustic enhancement and compressibility. These findings indicate a condition requiring immediate intervention rather than watchful waiting.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with anterior knee pain and swelling following repetitive kneeling activities at work. Physical examination shows localized tenderness and fluctuance over the anterior aspect of the knee with preserved passive range of motion. A point-of-care ultrasound performed using a 7–12 MHz linear array probe over the affected area is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis based on this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Knee joint effusion typically appears as anechoic fluid within the deeper joint space. While the suprapatellar bursa anatomically communicates with the knee joint cavity in most individuals, and joint effusions can extend into this space, this patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with primary bursal pathology. The preserved passive range of motion and occupational history of repetitive kneeling favor localized bursitis over a true joint effusion, which is more likely to restrict joint movement.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The anechoic fluid collection combined with the clinical context strongly suggests suprapatellar bursitis caused by occupational activities. The suprapatellar bursa, located deep to the quadriceps femoris muscle, can become inflamed and distended with fluid following repetitive trauma or overuse. While this bursa anatomically communicates with the knee joint cavity, the preserved passive range of motion and occupational history of repetitive kneeling indicate primary bursal inflammation rather than a joint effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis typically manifests as a more superficial fluid collection directly over the patella. The depth and characteristics of the fluid collection in this patient are more consistent with involvement of a deeper bursal structure than with involvement of the superficial prepatellar bursa.

D) INCORRECT:

Baker cysts occur in the popliteal fossa, posterior to the knee joint, and do not manifest as an anterior fluid collection.

E) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis appears as increased echogenicity and cobblestone appearance of subcutaneous tissue rather than a discrete anechoic fluid collection. The well-defined anechoic collection shown is characteristic of fluid within a contained space, not the diffuse tissue changes seen in cellulitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of lung cancer presents with acute dyspnea and hypotension. Ultrasound shows a large pericardial effusion with diastolic collapse of the right ventricle. A small amount of fluid is aspirated via ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis using the subxiphoid approach. Which ultrasound finding best confirms the correct needle position within the pericardial space before proceeding with therapeutic drainage?

choices.text: Echogenic stream appearance after agitated saline injection
Needle tip visualization adjacent to the myocardium
Reduction in the anechoic space around the heart
Needle tip movement with synchronous cardiac contractions
Disappearance of right ventricular diastolic collapse

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Agitated saline injection through the needle creates an echogenic stream that appears on ultrasound when the needle tip is properly positioned within the pericardial space. This technique provides definitive confirmation of correct needle placement before proceeding with therapeutic fluid removal. The echogenic appearance results from microbubbles created by mixing air and saline, which are clearly visible on ultrasound imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Needle tip visualization adjacent to the myocardium helps with procedural guidance but does not specifically confirm that the needle has entered the pericardial space rather than remaining in surrounding tissues. Visual confirmation of needle position requires additional methods to verify entry into the pericardial cavity.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduction in the anechoic space around the heart occurs during therapeutic fluid drainage after needle placement is confirmed. This finding suggests successful fluid removal but does not confirm initial proper needle positioning within the pericardial space.

D) INCORRECT:

Needle tip movement with synchronous cardiac contractions can occur whether the needle is properly positioned within the pericardial space or in contact with other cardiac structures. Therefore, this finding alone does not provide specific confirmation of correct needle placement within the pericardial cavity.

E) INCORRECT:

Disappearance of right ventricular diastolic collapse occurs after sufficient therapeutic fluid removal and suggests successful treatment of tamponade. This hemodynamic improvement happens after confirmed needle placement and adequate fluid drainage, not during initial needle positioning.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diabetes presents to the ED with a 2-day history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He appears ill with dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Vital signs are BP, 85/50; P, 125; R, 28; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F). Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, elevated lactate, and acute kidney injury. The patient is breathing spontaneously with adequate respiratory effort. An inferior vena cava (IVC) ultrasound is performed as part of a multimodal assessment of volume status. Which finding would be most consistent with this patient's clinical picture?

choices.text: Small IVC diameter with high respiratory variation
Normal IVC diameter with moderate respiratory variation
Large IVC diameter with minimal respiratory variation
Normal IVC diameter with no respiratory variation
Large IVC diameter with high respiratory variation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This finding is consistent with the basic physiological principle of volume depletion: venous return is reduced, resulting in a decreased IVC diameter. Additionally, in hypovolemic patients, there is greater respiratory variation of the IVC diameter because of the increased dependence on venous return during respiration. In patients who are breathing spontaneously, like this one, the IVC is narrowest during inspiration and widest during expiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure created during inspiration. This is general pattern associated with volume depletion; however, IVC ultrasound should always be interpreted in conjunction with other clinical parameters as part of a comprehensive assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

A normal IVC diameter suggests adequate venous return and is not a typical finding in volume depletion, which this patient likely has based on their clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

A large IVC diameter with minimal respiratory variation suggests elevated venous pressure, which is opposite to what is expected in volume depletion. Positive pressure ventilation can also reduce respiratory variation by increasing intrathoracic pressure, but this patient is breathing spontaneously.

D) INCORRECT:

Absent respiratory variation typically suggests elevated central venous pressure, which is inconsistent with volume depletion. While this pattern can also be seen in positive pressure ventilation due to increased intrathoracic pressure, this patient is breathing spontaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

A large IVC diameter is more consistent with volume overload than volume depletion. While high respiratory variation might suggest some degree of volume responsiveness, the large diameter contradicts the expected findings in volume depletion.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with acute respiratory distress syndrome develops signs of shock. Point-of-care ultrasound is performed as part of a multimodal assessment of fluid responsiveness. Which additional factor is least likely to limit the interpretation of the inferior vena cava (IVC) ultrasound?

choices.text: Severe metabolic acidosis from septic shock
Mixed ventilator mode with spontaneous breathing
Right heart dysfunction from pulmonary hypertension
Abdominal distention from positive pressure ventilation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – While severe metabolic acidosis significantly impacts overall patient management and may necessitate specific ventilator strategies, it does not directly interfere with the mechanical relationship between IVC diameter variation and intravascular volume status. The acidosis itself does not alter intrathoracic pressure, venous return patterns, or respiratory mechanics in ways that limit caval index interpretation.

B) INCORRECT:

Unpredictable respiratory patterns, including mixed ventilator modes that combine mandatory and spontaneous ventilation, limit the reliability of IVC findings because they create inconsistent intrathoracic pressure changes that affect venous return unpredictably.

C) INCORRECT:

Mechanical ventilation with high PEEP settings increases intrathoracic pressure, which reduces venous return and significantly limits the reliability of caval indices to predict fluid responsiveness.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress syndrome commonly leads to pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right heart dysfunction. Cardiac dysfunction, including right heart failure, significantly limits the reliability of IVC diameter variation by altering normal venous return patterns.

E) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure ventilation can cause abdominal distention, leading to increased intraabdominal pressure. This increase affects venous return and limits the interpretation of IVC ultrasound for the assessment of fluid responsiveness.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with progressive dyspnea and bilateral lower extremity edema. Initial chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and bilateral pulmonary edema. A subxiphoid inferior vena cava (IVC) ultrasound is performed to assess volume status. What is the best anatomical location to measure the IVC diameter?

choices.text: In the infrarenal portion of the IVC
At the point where the IVC crosses the diaphragm
Just distal to the IVC-right atrial junction
At the widest portion of the IVC visible on the screen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The infrarenal IVC is too distal from the heart to accurately reflect central venous pressure and volume status.

B) INCORRECT:

The diaphragmatic crossing point is not the standard measurement location for IVC assessment. Measurements at this level do not provide the standardized intrahepatic IVC evaluation needed for accurate volume status determination.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The intrahepatic IVC should be measured just distal to the IVC-right atrial junction or, alternatively, 2 cm caudal to the IVC-hepatic vein junction. This standardized location in the intrahepatic portion provides reproducible measurements for calculating the caval index and assessing volume status. The measurements should be taken in the midline of the vessel to avoid underestimating the diameter.

D) INCORRECT:

While the hepatic vein junction serves as an anatomical reference point, measurements should be taken 2 cm caudal to this junction rather than directly at the junction itself to obtain optimal diameter assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although measurements should be taken where the IVC appears widest in the longitudinal section, this must be at the specific anatomical landmark of the intrahepatic IVC near the right atrium to ensure standardized and clinically meaningful results.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with acute abdominal pain and back discomfort. Vital signs are BP, 145/90; P, 95. He appears uncomfortable but stable. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a uniform aortic appearance without wall irregularities. The aorta measures 3.2 cm in the transverse view and 3.1 cm in the longitudinal view. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography and vascular surgery consultation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The aortic measurements of 3.2 cm and 3.1 cm meet the diagnostic threshold for abdominal aortic aneurysm (≥ 3 cm). In a symptomatic patient with acute abdominal and back pain, this finding warrants CT angiography for detailed evaluation and vascular surgery consultation for management planning.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is insufficient when point-of-care ultrasound shows abdominal aortic aneurysm in a symptomatic patient. The combination of symptoms and confirmed aneurysm requires immediate specialist evaluation and advanced imaging to exclude rupture or impending rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate because the measurements exceed 3 cm, which meets the criteria for abdominal aortic aneurysm. This condition requires further evaluation and specialist consultation regardless of current stability.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical intervention is premature without confirmatory imaging and detailed evaluation. While this patient has abdominal aortic aneurysm, he appears stable and requires CT angiography first to assess for rupture and determine the most appropriate intervention approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat ultrasound delays necessary care and adds no diagnostic value when clear measurements have already been obtained. The priority is advanced imaging and specialist consultation, given the confirmed abdominal aortic aneurysm in a symptomatic patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and nausea. During abdominal point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) evaluation using a curvilinear transducer, the gallbladder is visible in the sagittal plane, but visualization of the gallbladder wall is poor. The image appears dark overall, making it difficult to assess for wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Additionally, the image includes bowel gas artifacts in the far field that are obscuring deeper structures. What is the most appropriate initial adjustment to optimize visualization of the gallbladder wall and surrounding structures?

choices.text: Switch to linear transducer and increase gain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While decreasing frequency might improve depth penetration, it would reduce image resolution. Increasing depth would reduce the spatial resolution of the gallbladder wall (the primary area of interest) and would not improve visualization distal to the bowel gas artifacts.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Increasing gain will brighten the dark image, improving visualization of the gallbladder wall and the ability to assess for wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid. Decreasing depth will increase focus on the gallbladder area of interest and improve spatial resolution.

C) INCORRECT:

Linear transducers are high-frequency probes designed for superficial structures, and they have poor depth penetration, making them inappropriate for most abdominal imaging. Curvilinear transducers are the preferred choice for gallbladder evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreasing gain would further darken an already dark image, making it impossible to assess the gallbladder wall. Increasing depth would reduce the spatial resolution of the gallbladder wall (the primary area of interest) and would not improve visualization distal to the bowel gas artifacts.

E) INCORRECT:

While decreasing depth would increase focus on the gallbladder area of interest and improve spatial resolution, increasing frequency would worsen depth penetration for abdominal structures in the far field. High-frequency transducers are appropriate for superficial structures, not deep abdominal organs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with flank pain. Point-of-care ultrasound of the epigastric area of the abdomen is shown. What do the ultrasound findings represent?

choices.text: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm with retroperitoneal hematoma
Abdominal aortic aneurysm with mural calcifications and acoustic artifacts
Aortic dissection with intimal flap and periaortic fluid
Normal aorta obscured by overlying bowel gas artifacts
Abdominal aortic aneurysm with contained rupture and active bleeding

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A retroperitoneal hematoma, which is usually poorly visible on ultrasound, would appear as a hypoechoic collection. In this patient's ultrasound, the hypoechoic bands seen along the edges of the aorta and in the far field are consistent with acoustic shadowing, which commonly occurs distal to calcifications and at the edges of fluid-filled structures. The hyperechoic tissue behind the vessel represents acoustic enhancement from fluid transmission.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The image shows a dilated abdominal aorta, indicating an aneurysm. The bright echogenic areas along the vessel wall with posterior acoustic shadowing represent mural calcifications that strongly absorb ultrasound waves. Acoustic shadowing is also visible extending from the edges of the aorta. This is a common refraction artifact caused by fluid-filled structures. The hyperechoic appearance of tissue behind the fluid-filled lumen is a result of acoustic enhancement, which occurs because ultrasound waves are minimally attenuated by fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's ultrasound shows an aortic aneurysm with a mural thrombus and calcified vessel walls. An intimal flap would appear as a separated, often mobile, echogenic structure within the lumen. The posterior acoustic enhancement and acoustic shadowing visible at the aortic edges most likely represent acoustic artifacts from intraaortic fluid rather than periaortic fluid collections.

D) INCORRECT:

The aorta is visible in its entirety in this image, and it is dilated well beyond normal caliber, indicating an aneurysm. Bowel gas creates reverberation artifacts with parallel lines, not the discrete acoustic shadowing from calcifications seen in this image.

E) INCORRECT:

While an aneurysm is visible on this patient's ultrasound, the acoustic enhancement artifact behind the lumen results from normal fluid transmission properties, not active bleeding. Contained ruptures have a surrounding hematoma, which appears as a hypoechoic fluid collection. There is no visible evidence of disrupted aortic wall integrity in this image. The pattern of hypoechoic lines trailing from the edge of the aorta and distal to the hyperechoic calcifications is most consistent with an acoustic shadowing artifact, not bleeding.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 6 weeks' gestation presents with pelvic pain and spotting. She is hemodynamically stable and her β-hCG is 8,800 mIU/mL. Point-of-care ultrasound shows an intrauterine pregnancy with a gestational sac and visible cardiac activity within the fetal pole. What is the most appropriate next step for assessing fetal viability that adheres to the ALARA (as low as reasonably achievable) principle?

choices.text: Increase gain settings to enhance cardiac visualization
Switch to M-mode to confirm fetal heart activity
Extend scanning time to document fetal measurements
Apply color Doppler to visualize cardiac blood flow
Switch to transvaginal approach for enhanced imaging

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing gain settings does not reduce acoustic exposure and may introduce artifacts that compromise image quality. The ALARA principle emphasizes using the minimum acoustic output necessary for diagnostic purposes rather than enhancing image parameters unnecessarily.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- M-mode is the appropriate technique for confirming fetal heart activity in early pregnancy. M-mode provides adequate assessment of cardiac activity while maintaining the lowest acoustic output consistent with the ALARA principle, avoiding the higher energy outputs of Doppler modes that may pose risks to the developing fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Extended scanning time increases cumulative fetal exposure to ultrasound energy, which does not follow the ALARA principle. Once fetal cardiac activity is confirmed, prolonged scanning should be avoided unless clinically necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Color Doppler ultrasound should be avoided in first-trimester pregnancies because it uses higher acoustic energy output than necessary for basic cardiac assessment. This does not follow the ALARA principle, which emphasizes avoiding fetal exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Switching to a transvaginal approach is unnecessary if adequate visualization has already been achieved transabdominally, as it increases examination time and fetal exposure without providing additional clinically relevant information for emergency assessment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He has left-sided chest pain and mild dyspnea. Vital signs are BP, 128/82; P, 98; R, 22; SpO2, 96% on room air. A basic lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE) protocol is performed at the upper and lower BLUE points bilaterally. Findings at the left lower BLUE point are shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The finding visible on this patient's ultrasound is the lung point, which is indicative of air in the pleural space that requires management beyond supportive care and follow-up.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the lung point seen on this patient's ultrasound is pathognomonic for pneumothorax, needle thoracostomy is reserved for tension pneumothorax. This patient has stable vital signs and no sign of respiratory distress, respiratory failure, or hemodynamic compromise, making needle decompression an inappropriate step at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a lung point on point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is pathognomonic for pneumothorax, POCUS cannot reliably quantify the size of the pneumothorax, which is required to determine if chest tube insertion is indicated in this hemodynamically stable patient with minimal symptoms, no signs of hemothorax, and no anticipated need for mechanical ventilation. In stable patients, traumatic pneumothoraces that are ≤ 35 mm (measured from the chest wall to the pleura in the largest air pocket) can be safely managed conservatively. Further imaging is required in this patient to determine the size of the pneumothorax.

D) INCORRECT:

Thoracentesis is appropriate if unexplained fluid is visible in the pleural cavity. The finding seen here is a lung point, which indicates pleural air, not fluid.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Although a lung point on point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is pathognomonic for pneumothorax, POCUS cannot reliably quantify the size of the pneumothorax, which is required to determine if chest tube insertion is indicated in this hemodynamically stable patient with minimal symptoms. Chest x-ray is nevertheless indicated to guide management, even if the diagnosis is established.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents after a motor vehicle collision with chest pain and dyspnea. Vital signs are BP, 88/55; HR, 118; R, 26. eFAST examination of the right chest is shown. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The eFAST findings show hemothorax, evidenced by the hypoechoic collection in the dependent pleural space (costodiaphragmatic recess). In trauma patients, any free fluid within the pleural spaces should be considered pathological. eFAST can reliably detect as little as 100 mL of pleural fluid, and hemothorax requires drainage via chest tube insertion to prevent complications such as clotting and trapped lung.

B) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracostomy is indicated for tension pneumothorax, but the hypoechoic fluid collection in the right costodiaphragmatic recess of this patient is consistent with hemothorax rather than a pneumothorax.

C) INCORRECT:

Further imaging would delay necessary intervention if eFAST has already identified pathological pleural fluid requiring immediate drainage. In this trauma patient with hemodynamic compromise, the ultrasound findings are sufficient to guide immediate management.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency thoracotomy is indicated for massive hemothorax, but this is typically reserved for cases with specific criteria or inadequate response to initial chest tube drainage. The initial management of hemothorax should begin with chest tube insertion to establish drainage and assess ongoing blood loss. If this patient were to lose vital signs in the emergency department, resuscitative thoracotomy would be indicated. Emergency thoracotomy is also appropriate if chest tube output exceeds either 1500 mL immediately or 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, or if the patient has cardiac tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

The pleural view findings do not suggest pericardial pathology. Pericardiocentesis is indicated for pericardial effusion identified on ultrasound, not for pleural space fluid collections seen on pleural views. Additionally, in traumatic hemopericardium, pericardiocentesis is not first-line therapy because clotted blood often cannot be aspirated and reaccumulates rapidly. For traumatic cardiac tamponade, the definitive treatment is emergency thoracotomy with surgical pericardiotomy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old driver presents after a motor vehicle collision with steering wheel impact. Initial vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 88; R, 20. On examination, there is mild left upper quadrant tenderness. eFAST of the right upper quadrant is shown. Fifteen minutes later, repeat vital signs are BP, 94/60; P, 105. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with precautions and follow-up instructions
Perform serial abdominal examinations and repeat eFAST in 1 hour
Administer 2 liters of crystalloid and reassess in 30 minutes
Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Initiate blood transfusion and consult surgery immediately

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate for any trauma patient with positive eFAST findings, especially a patient with hemodynamic deterioration that suggests active bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Serial examinations and delayed repeat imaging are inappropriate if a patient has signs of hemodynamic instability and positive eFAST findings, which suggest ongoing bleeding that requires immediate intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Although fluid resuscitation may be initiated, the combination of positive eFAST findings and hemodynamic deterioration indicates active bleeding that requires urgent surgical evaluation rather than conservative management.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scan may eventually be useful, but this patient's deteriorating hemodynamic status and positive eFAST findings require immediate intervention rather than additional imaging, which would delay definitive management.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Hemodynamic deterioration (decreasing blood pressure, increasing heart rate) and a positive eFAST finding of free fluid in the hepatorenal space indicate active intraperitoneal bleeding, which requires immediate surgical consultation and blood product preparation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lung cancer presents to the emergency department with fatigue and dyspnea. He is alert and oriented. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 124; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Point-of-care ultrasound examination is shown. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although tension pneumothorax can occur in patients with lung cancer who have dyspnea and hemodynamic instability, it does not cause a hypoechoic collection around the heart, which is seen on this patient's ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest tube placement is appropriate for treating pneumothorax or hemothorax, which can occur in patients with lung cancer who have dyspnea and hemodynamic instability. Pneumothorax and hemothorax do not, however, result in a hypoechoic collection around the heart, which is seen on this patient's ultrasound. Drainage of the pleural space does not address the condition most likely causing this patient's clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's ultrasound finding of a hypoechoic collection around the heart is diagnostic for a pericardial effusion with tamponade, emergency thoracotomy is not the first-line treatment. Emergency thoracotomy is usually reserved for patients in cardiac arrest or with traumatic cardiac tamponade.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ultrasound finding of an anechoic rim around the heart confirms pericardial effusion, most likely of malignant origin. In hemodynamically unstable patients with cardiac tamponade, immediate pericardiocentesis is the preferred treatment to decompress the pericardial space.

E) INCORRECT:

The ultrasound finding of an anechoic rim around the heart confirms pericardial effusion causing cardiac tamponade in this hemodynamically unstable patient. Fluid resuscitation should only be attempted with caution in patients with obstructive shock because it can paradoxically worsen cardiac tamponade by increasing venous return and pericardial pressure. Treating the underlying cause of obstructive shock is the safest option.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man, who is a construction worker, presents to the emergency department after stepping on debris at a worksite. Physical examination reveals a small puncture wound on the sole of his right foot with mild surrounding erythema. Which point-of-care ultrasound finding most likely indicates a wooden foreign body?

choices.text: Irregular echogenic object with posterior acoustic shadowing
Smooth echogenic object with distal reverberation artifacts
Circular hypoechoic object with posterior acoustic enhancement
Circular echogenic object surrounded by hypoechoic halo without posterior shadowing
Increased echogenicity and irregular appearance of subcutaneous tissue

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Wooden splinters appear on ultrasound as irregularly shaped echogenic objects with acoustic shadows created by their irregular surface properties. The nonuniform texture of wood absorbs and scatters sound waves, resulting in characteristic shadowing posterior to the object.

B) INCORRECT:

Metallic foreign bodies appear on ultrasound as smooth echogenic objects that produce reverberation artifacts, which are not a typical finding of wooden foreign bodies. The smooth surface of metal causes sound waves to bounce back and forth between the transducer and the object.

C) INCORRECT:

An abscess appears on ultrasound as a circular hypoechoic area with posterior acoustic enhancement due to improved sound transmission through fluid. This finding is not characteristic of solid foreign bodies such as wood.

D) INCORRECT:

While a hypoechoic halo on ultrasound could represent an inflammatory response around a foreign body present for more than 24 hours, the circular shape and absence of shadowing are not typical for wooden foreign bodies, which characteristically produce acoustic shadows and have irregular, splinter-like linear shapes.

E) INCORRECT:
